@smallx, I think my suggestion to check whether the table was cached to control whether to call the session catalog invalidate was a bad one. It introduces a lot of code for not much benefit, like needing to look up whether a table was cached before evicting it. Let's just go with the original approach of invalidating everywhere. If @RussellSpitzer is okay with that, then so am I.
Thanks, @kbendick!
I'm closing this one in favor of #3870. Thanks, @ZhangChaoming!
Thanks, @nastra!
I can try to fix it.

> I would personally say if there's no practical difference between the two, it would be ok to make them into one function.
Possibly there could be one outer function, that contains all of the shared logic (like the interrupted exception and SQLException checks). And then two different functions that wrap that function with a code block for the building of the correct prepared statement. This might make the changes a bit easier to digest and be cleaner, but it's fine as it is otherwise.

It seemed like the way to go from other catalogs. So I separated them out to separate methods.

> * Also issues will arise if we start expiring snapshots. If one catalog decides that one of the files are not needed anymore, then it could remove the file, even if the file is still needed for the other table.
>

@kbendick , @rdblue let me know if you have more comments. I addressed the latest comments in the commits.

@yittg, I'm skeptical that this is the right approach. The dynamic class loader allows you to specify the classloader to use. It is generally better to specify the correct one instead of relying on the context loader.

In this case, it looks like the [reader used to load the file's key-value metadata](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/ManifestReader.java#L100-L102) doesn't have the class loader set like the [reader used to scan the manifest](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/ManifestReader.java#L207). I would first try setting the class loader the same way.

> In this case, it looks like the [reader used to load the file's key-value metadata](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/ManifestReader.java#L100-L102) doesn't have the class loader set like the [reader used to scan the manifest](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/ManifestReader.java#L207). I would first try setting the class loader the same way.

@rdblue  It's also my first choice, FYI https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/3776#issuecomment-998502908, but it's not enough, as described in my comment, you can not pass the correct one to all cases in the dependencies.

> For example, the follow code snippet in [java.xml](https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/jdk-11%2B12/src/java.xml/share/classes/javax/xml/parsers/FactoryFinder.java#L285)
> ```
> final ServiceLoader<T> serviceLoader = ServiceLoader.load(type);
> ```

IMO, the right way is not to use the static shared thread pool. But it's hard to fix here, the shared pool is involved in too many places.

So i choose this quick fix to walk around it.

Hi @hililiwei. Thanks for looking into this.

My thoughts are:
1) We tend to prefer method calls that don't use `get` in the name (or `set`). Either some other verb is used to be more informative (examples like `find`, etc) or we just don't use `get` since it likely provides little meaning if there isn't a more specific verb to use. That's probably why we have the two methods. So if we do remove one, it would be more in line with the project style to keep `.conf()` and remove `.getConf()`.
2) This is a rather old API. My opinion is we can't necessarily be sure if people are depending on this API or not. I'm interested in hearing other people's opinions on this, but I think it might be safer to keep both and mark `getConf` (or at least one of them) as deprecated.

Please don't spend the time updating the PR to use `conf()` instead of `getConf()` unless somebody else chimes in though so you don't make unnecessary updates
@kbendick  thanks for your comment, already got your gist.Let's wait for others' suggestions and then consider whether to make this change.

Since it is `Hadoop`FileIo, I think it is "natural" to expect it to implement `org.apache.hadoop.conf.Configurable`. That would mean that we would want to keep `getConf()`. OTOH in Iceberg `conf()` is the way to access attributes.

I would vote for keeping both, but a comment might be useful to encourage the usage of the `conf()` method.
Close this because it not be a general problem and can be solved by starting Hive housekeeper services. Thanks everyone.

Maybe I understand you wrong, If you can elaborate a bit more in detail, I am happy to do it!
Ah I totally forgot, I think it's fine then. It just makes it harder for me to check all the changes. I'll merge after we  fix up the few spacing nits.

Unfortunately I do not believe we are guaranteed that History is ordered (WAP commits) or Complete (History has a max length) so I do not believe we can rely on it. The only true way to view the lineage is the recursive approach being used.

This could be another case of our CommitStateUnknown states. When the status cannot be checked we need to keep the files created. I believe this was very recently patched [here](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3717)

@RussellSpitzer, I added newline as suggested by you in baseAction for spark 2.4/3.0/3.1/3.2 and confirmed that they are all the same before and after my change, I hope that helps! 

Also looks like CI still need your approval to run for the spacing change

```
  iceberg git:(master) diff spark/v2.4/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/actions/BaseDeleteOrphanFilesSparkAction.java spark/v3.0/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/actions/BaseDeleteOrphanFilesSparkAction.java
  iceberg git:(master) diff spark/v2.4/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/actions/BaseDeleteOrphanFilesSparkAction.java spark/v3.1/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/actions/BaseDeleteOrphanFilesSparkAction.java
  iceberg git:(master) diff spark/v2.4/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/actions/BaseDeleteOrphanFilesSparkAction.java spark/v3.2/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/actions/BaseDeleteOrphanFilesSparkAction.java
```
Yep! Clicked it off, you will have full auth to run any CI after we merge this so you won't need me anymore :D

OOM's can happen for a lot of reasons, did you see a memory leak? Or monotonically increasing heap size? I would make sure it isn't one particular merge causing the issue before diagnosing. 

The Error there looks like an Operating System kill, so it's not explicitly a JVM thing either. It could just be that the container is too small for the heap + offheap usage configured in spark.

I would look at the Spark Connectors for those other systems, it should be much more efficient than writing your own sinks in the foreach. For example

spark.read.format("iceberg")....write.format("jdbc) ....
Tests Passed and Merged! Thanks @anuragmantri and all reviewers!
